column10: Waterlust is a small family-run business that donates 10% of their profits to various research & education organizations. They ship in 100% recycled, recyclable and biodegradable paper, and packaged in a recycled and recyclable poly mailer bags. They have a line that donates 100% of profits to the Black Girls Dive Foundation. They do not use animal products.

Knotty Tie Co. provides employment opportnities for refugees by offering jobs that match their skill, reimburse for education, give training, pay a living wage, and cover health insurance, transit and fitness expenses.. Their products are made and manufactored in Colorado, USA, and they ship in recyclable packaging. They do not use animal products

Offset Jewelry plants 10 trees to offset the carbon footprint of each item, which can be tracked and seen by each customer. They ship in minimal, FSCÂ®-certified packaging. They manufactor in BSCI certified and ISO 9001:QMS certified facilities that use low carbon emitting metals for their base material.  They do not publish impact reports publicly or share if their employees are paid a living wage. They do not use animal products.

Hershey sources palm oil from at least 20 different farms that continue the destruction of rainforest to harvest. In 2017, investigations found Herhsey used cocoa grown illegally in national parks in Ghana and Ivory Coast. In 2019, another undercover investigation by the Rainforest Action Network found they were one of several large corporations sourcing palm oil from growers illegally, clearing lowland rainforests inside the nationally protected Rawa Singkil Wildlife Reserve in Indonesia. In 2020, Hershey became a signatory for the Cocoa & Forests Initiative, which seeks to end deforestation and restore forest areas. As You Sow scored them an F for their contribution to plastic pollution and lack of corporate leadership with their single-use packaging. They rated a Tier 5 (6 being the worst) on the Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare for their lack of implementaion of animal welfare practices. They scored a 22% on their Know the Chain benchmark, which scores how they address human trafficking and forced labor in their supply chain. In 2019, Michele Buck (CEO of Hershey) paid themself $17 million in salary, 441 times the median employee's pay of  about $38,000. Hershey scored in the 20-30% range on the Human Rights Benchmark, which was an average score among other brands.

Birch Babe Naturals is a beauty brand selling plant-based, minimally-packaged, and plastic-free cosmetics. They do not use palm oil, and include their ingredients on their listings. They claim to be "Certified Natural" but do not share who has certified them or what it means. They do not share where they source their materials and ingredients from, or if they pay their employees a living wage.

Nespresso is owned by Nestle, who rates a 1.0 on Ethicli. Nespresso is Fairtrade certified and Rainforest Alliance certified. They make their capsules out of recyclable aluminum, however in some areas they have to be collected and returned to a Nespresso retailer in order to be recycled again. Single-use capsules are relatively less sustainable than traditional brewing methods. The current recycling rate of capsules are approximately 30%. There is little transparency about their environmental impact reports or fair wages. They have pledged to become carbon-neutral by 2022 by partnering with the PUR Project. Nespresso capsules do not contain animal products.

Zip Top sells reusable 100% Platinum food-grade Silicone containers as an alternative to ziploc single-use plastic bags. They are BPA-free, plastic-free, and PVC-free. They do not use animal products, and the containers are recyclable. All of their products are made in the USA, but they do not state where or how their silicone is sourced. Additionally, specific information about their labor practices is not transparent to shoppers.

Tera Cube is a sustainable smartphone alternative that is meant to be repairable instead of continually upgraded. They come with a 4-year warranty, fully compostable case, replaceable battery, and are made from recycled materials for a relatively cheaper price (around $250) compared to other phones. They use minimal packaging from recycled paper and soy ink. Their USB charger is also compatible with other phone companies to reduce the need for new cables. They claim that with every phone sold, they plant a tree.

UnderArmour scored a 100% on the Corporate Equality Index, which distinguishes best companies for LGBTQ equality. Under Armour scored the lowest rating for Labour Behind the Label's rating for businesses' committments to pay their workers a living wage. The SAM Corporate Sustainability Assessment from S&P Global scored them a 10/100 for their supply chain practices. In 2019, As You Sow rated Under Armour a 42.7% for how their mineral sourcing affects human rights. In 2019, Kevin Plank (CEO of Under Armour) paid himself $6 million in salary, 491 times the median employee's pay of $12,127. They scored a 29/100 in the Fashion Transparency Index, and a 30-40% range in the Human Rights Benchmark, both scores being slightly above average. Under Armour scored a 44/100 (above average) on their efforts to limit human trafficking in their supply chain. They do use animal products like leather certified by the Leather Working Group, and wool. They are a participating member of the Fair Labor Association to improve working conditions, and a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.

SiiZU is a New York-based fashion brand that focuses on sustainability in their supply chain. They use eco-friendly materials such as Tencel (wood pulp processed to form cellulose fibers) and recycled oyster shells that provides a non-wool alternative, and share the sourcing of their materials on their website. They use vegan leather, but also use silk, cashmere, and wool that is BlueSign and WoolMark certified. They are a corporate partner to American Forests, which helps reforest wildlife habitat. They claim that all their eco-friendly materials are 100% organic. They commit to sourcing from partners that pay a fair wage to their workers. SiiZU shares where their products are made on their website as well, with links leading to more information about each fabrics' facility. As for their jewelry, they do not share information whether their gold and silver jewelry is mined from raw materials, or made from recycled ore. They manufacture in the US, China and Japan.

Parks Project is an organization focusing on initiatives with restoration, youth and advocacy education, and visitor programs with the money made from donations and apparel sales. They partner with numerous conservancies such as the Grand Canyon Conservancy, National Park Foundation, and Yellowstone Forever.  In their facilities, they claim to use LED-certified energy, use BlueSign-certified dyes, and less energy-intensive machinery that is standard to EPA regulations. All paper products are Forest Stewardship Council certified, and they process their water through a filtration system to be recycled.

ThredUP is the world's largest online thrift store that reduces apparel waste with circular buyback programs and reselling used clothing. They transparently publish resale reports, ecological impact reports, carbon footprint calculators, methodologies, sources and past reports on their website. Their independent non-profit "Circular Fashion Fund" supports small businesses who commit to progressing sustainable fashion. Their "Remade" line, debuted in 2018, was critisized for greenwashing as the items are not truly sourced from upcycled materials. A total of 501 complaints have been filed from 2018-2020 with the Better Business Bureau.

La Croix is a USA-based sparkling water brand. La Croix sells water in aluminum cans, which are recyclable. However, when bauxite is mined to make aluminum, it causes habitat loss, water contamination, and erosion, and other environmentally damaging aspects. La Croix does not claim to make their cans from recycled aluminum. They have a lower carbon footprint for transportation compared to other imported waters, however they do not share information about their environmental impact publicly. They are vegan and do not use animal products. There have been two lawsuits over CEO Nick Caporella accused of sexually harrassing two former employee pilots over 30 trips between 2014 and 2016. In 2019, The CEO was critisized for blaming his drop in shares on "injustice" and dehumanizing people with disabilities by comparing the act of taking care of them to managing a brand, claiming they "do not see or hear, so they are at the mercy of their owners or care providers who must preserve [their] dignity and special character". La Croix additionally does not share information publicly online regarding whether they pay their workers a fair wage.

Top of the Mornin Coffee sell organic, specialty grade coffee from local farms that is carbon-neutral imported. They partner (under their parent organization, Akira Coffee Co.) with the Feya Foundation to combat hunger by donating a meal for every order from their store. Information about third-party certifications, their environmental impact, or whether they pay their employees a living wage is not publicly transparent on their webiste. They share some information about where they source their materials. They use dairy in some of their products.

EarthEasy is a small, family-owned Vancouver-based home & garden company seeking to make off-grid living easier for people. They've partnered with Trees.org to plant over 90,000 trees for every purchase, which is traceable on their website. They balance their carbon footprint with TerraPass, which as of December of 2020 was 26 metric Tons, which also is traceable to the public. They are an EPA WaterSense partner to promote water conservation, and GreenAmerica-approved. They have not shared information online about whether they pay a living wage or where they source their materials from, as they are a distributor for other brands.

Package Free Shop ships and sells items in no-plastic, 100% recyclable and compostable packaging. They partner with Pachama to offset carbon through reforestation projects. They have donated to organizations including ACLU, Black Girls Code, Habitat for Humanity, and Lower East Ecology Center. They plan to become B-Corp certified by 2021.They pay their warehouse associates and employees a living wage.

Nothing New makes carbon-neutral, vegan shoes made from 100% recycled materials. They also recycle their shoes to create a circular program reducing waste. The recycled plastics they use are 100% Global Recycle Standard certified. They source their ocean-bound plastic bottles internationally in accordance to the United Nations Global Compact principles and International Labor Organization, but it is unclear if they pay their employees a living wage.

Safeway is owned by Albertsons. is a grocer that partnered with The Ethical Charter on Responsible Labor Practices in 2018. Lawsuits include a class action lawsuit for gauging prices on essential items during the increased demand of items during the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, and a $75,000 charge to Settle an EEOC Disability Discrimination Lawsuit. Their website allows shoppers to order online in order to help people receive groceries from home and continue social distancing. They transparently publish their sustainability reports on their website and have a clear statement on Anti-Human Trafficking, Accessibility statements and resources, and other documents. Their west coast divisions signed onto the Pacific Coast Collaborative as a commitment to reduce food waste by 50% by 2030. They are a Visionary Partner for "Feeding America" and "Hunger Is", and partner with food banks to donate excess food. In 2019, they won the EPA Safer Choice Partner of the Year Award for the third year. Their shipping trucks also are a member of Truckers Against Trafficking, which is a training program to help truck drivers identify trafficking behaviours on the road.

Eco Roots is a marketplace that sells plastic-free and cruelty-free, zero-waste products from small business. They are a 1% for the Ocean partner, donating a portion of every sale to the Ocean Conservancy.  Their branded soaps, hair products and cleaning supplies are vegan, and their products ship plastic-free in recyclable packaging. They also have a selection of palm oil - free products. Each listing transparently publishes ingredients and details about the brand they are selling. They claim to use GOTS certified organic cotton and bamboo, and use other eco-friendly materials. It is unclear from their website what their labor practices are or if their employees are paid a living wage.

Crabtree & Evelyn is owned by Nan Hai Corporation. Their products are not vegan or cruelty-free, and sends their products to third parties for animal testing when selling in countries that require animal testing by law. They ship in recyclable packaging made from post-consumer materials. The Good Shopping Guide rates C&E's soaps at a 58/100 for their animal products and ethical accreditation. EWG's Skin Deep ratings for the brand range on the below average to poor score scale (40-70%), which rates for the products' criteria for transparency and health. At least twice, the company has also been alleged to retaliate against its employees on two occasions. It is unclear if they pay their workers a living or minimum wage or if they contribute to forced labor along their supply chains. They do not publish Corporate Sustainability Reports or their environmental impact reports transparently.

Hara is an eco-fashion label using OEKO-TEX 100 approved organic bamboo to form apparel that does not use animal products, reduces water requirements, and ships in minimal packaging. They donate some of their proceeds to the Environmental Justice Foundation which funds projects to reduce the use of farmworkers handling harmful pesticides and fertilizers in the cotton supply chain. Their products are made locally in Bali, and the final stage in Australia where there is a low risk for labor violations and the supply chain can be traced. They operate under the Australian Textile, Clothing, Footwear award of 2010 to enforce fair working conditions and a living wage.

REI is a recreational equipment cooperative. They are very transparent with information about their sustainability, stewardship, and labor practices (and where they can improve) on their website. They publish documents like their list of Factory Partners that make it easy for the average shopper to trace their supply chain. They also publish their Carbon emission numbers directly on their website.They use BlueSign certified textiles, and support research devoted to reducing microplastic waste that leads to the ocean. They partner with the Sierra Club, Sustainable Apparel Coalition, and Textile Exchange. They do use animal products but offer a wide selection of RDS-certified wool, Leather Working Group certified, and vegan options that are filterable in their online marketplace.They do not appear to pay a living wage as of 2020.

Muji is a Japanese retail company focusing its philosophy on simplicity, minimalism, and the value of self-restraint. The company, however, sources much of its materials from unsustainable materials like unrecycled plastics and polymers, and manufacturers in China, Vietnam, and Indonesia where labor violation risks are high. They are not transparent about their company practices, labor practices, or environmental impact, and they do not share information regarding whether they use animal products.

The Real Real is a luxury goods company that extends the life of designer apparel. They plan to go Carbon neutral by 2021. They offer a series of documents on their website that transparently state their policies on Human Rights, Climate Change, Diversity and others. They are transparent about their workplace diversity with a breakdown based on self-identified reporting. They are a member of the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, One Tree Planted: Million Tree Challenge, and Sustainable Apparel Coalition. They are not transparent about their labor practices, and they do resell 2nd-hand items with animal products such as fur coats.

Poshmark is a second-hand online marketplace that allows users to buy and sell used clothing and accessorties. Poshmark is not very transparent about their business practices, and consumer reports have suggested sellers are often frauded, and buyers are sometimes scammed due to lack of regulation. Some shops sell handmade goods, and Poshmark has also often been critisized for culturally insensitive listings. Note: At this time we are only able to score Poshmark as a company. This score does not reflect individual shops or listings.

Bath & Body Works is owned by CEO Leslie Wexner or L Brands, and a sister company to Victoria's Secret. It is not a cruelty free shop, as they either test on animals, pay for animal testing, or sell in mainland China. CEO Wexner has been critisized for his involvement with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, and is paid 280 times the amount salary of the median employee. This company performed "very poorly" on Censible's ESG scores for pollution prevention, workplace health and safety, corporate governance, and forced labor, "poorly" for their carbon footprint and workplace diversity, "average" for water conservation, but "well" for data and privacy protection. They do use untraceable palm oil in their products.

Tokyo Otaku Mode lacks transparency in their business practices when it comes to how they treat their employees, their sustainability, and use of animal products. With little no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 (approximately average) until further notice.

AeroPress is a manufactorer of coffee and espresso makers that requires no electricity. Since they only require the energy needed to hand-press the coffee, they are energetically efficient. The company is transparent about their material development, stating their presses are made from BPA-free polypropylene and food-grade silicone. In November 2020, they partnered with Cookies for Kids' Cancer, which rates a 100/100 on Charity Navigator, to grant $100,000 to a researcher who innovates less toxic cancer treatments. The paper filters are reusable and AeroPress is made in the USA. They do not use animal products. AeroPress lacks transparency in their employee practices and whether they pay a living wage.

Thrive Causemetics is a Leaping Bunny certified vegan and cruelty-free brand. They have multiple charity partners, one being the Bigger Than Beauty with whom they donated 100% of their hand sanitizer proceeds to support the Black Womenâs Health Imperative to protect and advance Black women and girls' health and wellness. They also donated $1 million to the COVID-19 Response Fund, and $500,000 worth of Thrive Causemetics products to frontline workers. Thrive Causemetics products are transparently listed both on their website and on EWG's Skin Deep Cosmetics website to show and explain each ingredient used. They are not transparent about their environmental impact or labor practices.

Neiman Marcus is a luxury department store that filed for bankruptcy in May of 2020, but was bought out by other investment firms. They do not publicly share information about their environmental impact, whether they pay their employees fairly, or ship in aco-friendly materials. The company has partnered with JOANN Stores to donate 65,000 items of personal protective equipment, and are a partner of Boys & Girls Clubs Of America who have donated $500,000 in healthy after-school snacks or hours of homework help to young people. They do use animal products like leather, crocodile, wool, and fur, and in 2013 settled a federal charges for selling fur coats made from racoon dogs marketed as "faux fur". In 2018, a class action lawsuit was filed due to Neiman Marcus allegedly using an unlawful pay structure for some of its sales associates, which was moved to federal court. Another lawsuit was filed by an employee who claims Neiman Marcus violated the American Disabilities Act.

DoTerra is a Utah-based multi-level marketing (MLM) essential oil brand. They are not certified cruelty-free and sell in mainland China, which requires animal testing for imported cosmetics. They ship in recyclable materials and have several initiative to source sustainably. They source their Douglas Fir from invasive overgrowth forests in New Zealand, and Frankincense is collected using measures to preserve the tree. The company does not share reports however on their environmental impacts, their labor practices in their supply chain, or whether they pay their employees a living wage. In 2013, the U.S. Food & Drug Administration filed an warning for violating the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, with claims that doTerra oils are possible cures for autism and cancer. Company distributors later claimed in 2017 (around the time of the California wildfires) that their oils purify the air and help with the effects of smoke, which is a false and unfounded claim. The company was issued another warning in 2020 for unlawful claims that their products could prevent consumers from COVID-19, and can boost immunity to ward it off. Allegations also arose that doTerra took advantage of Hurricane Harvey to profit off of relief efforts, which cost $100 donations for 4 hygiene kits (a towel, toothbrush, and doTerra samples) which arrived late and were criticized for being unreasonably upcharged. doTerra does extensive chemical testing on their oils using their Certified Pure Therapeutic Grade protocol, however this testing is not an official, independent certification, because it is done internally and not by a third-party source that can guarantee the results. They claim third-party testing is done to guarantee transparency, however the names of these organizations are not shared, and the results of this testing is not transparently published for shoppers to see.

Whiskers Laces is a small company of 4 employees who create shoe laces made from nylon and polyester made from 100% recycled ocean-bound plastic bottles. They come with a storage spool made from sustainably sourced Birch bark from Maine, USA, which they take back with an upcycling program. Their products are made in the USA in North Carolina, and they source locally within 100 miles of their headquarters. Their 4 employees are paid a living wage. They ship in recycled cardboard packaging. Whiskers does not use animal products in their supply chain. They create dedicated shoelaces throughout the year to donate a portion of the proceeds to a given organization, for example their rainbow laces earning funds for the Trevor Project, and pink laces for breast cancer research.

Outdoor Voices is an athletic apparel company. They state their progressive sustainability goals on their website, however they do not publish their sustainability or environmental impact reports on their website for the public to see. Outdoor Voices uses some recycled or recyclable shipping packaging but still uses poly plastic bags. The company claims to use a number of eco-friendly and Bluesign certified fabrics, however when searching BlueSign's directory, the company does not show up as a partner. The same occurs for their alleged partnership with WWF, which cannot be found on WWF's website nor Outdoor Voices' site. Outdoor Voices does use recycled wool in their fleece fabric, but they do not disclose where they source their materials publicly. The company does not disclose whether they pay their employees a living or fair wage. An investigation By Buzzfeed News anonymously interviewed employees who stated the company did not properly compensate them for work done, that they had a toxic work culture that frequently used intimidation, and did not foster diversity but participated in "woke-washing" on their website to garner social credit. Along with financial struggles, Tyler Haney later stepped down as CEO.

Howies is an activewear brand that makes clothing from eco-friendly materials such as organic cotton, hemp, modal, and recycled or recyclable fabrics. They are transparent on their website about where they source their materials worldwide, and how they comply with Oeko-Tex and the Global Organic Textile Standard. They also state they work with their manufacturers to pay at least minimum wage, but some have transitioned to living wage pay. They use recyclable plastic bags to ship due to the greater opportunity for them to be recycled in the UK, reduction of weight in shipping, and protection of their clothing. They use animal products such as leather and wool in their clothing. In 2016, they were the first clothing company to go 100% PET and PFC-free. Some information is lacking such as where and how their animal products are sourced, and their environmental impact reports.

Scandinavian Designs does not share information about their business practices online in a way that is transparent for shoppers They do not indicate if they are FSC (Forest Stewardship Council) Certified, and are not certified by the Better Business Bureau, but score an A+ on the site. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.

UGG has transparent information on their website about how they source their sheepskin and has a clear animal welfare policy that can be easily accessed. They source their sheepskin from countries that have clear and regulated animal welfare policies in their supply chain: Australia, USA, UK, Spain, and Ireland. They source 98% of their products from by-products of animals that were raised for the food industry. Their wool is non-mulesed and their down is compliant with the Responsible Down Standard. Their leather is Leather Working Group Certified (Under Deckers Outdoor Corporation). UGG donated $125,000 to GLAAD â a nonprofit accelerating acceptance & advancing equality for the LGBTQ+ community. UGG scored a 17% in the Fashion Transparency Index. They do not share information about whether workers along their supply chain are paid a living wage. For environmental impact, UGG earned a 7/100 on their The Green Supply Chain CITI Evaluation for their practices in China, where their products are made. They sell "Dakota" moccasins however their moccasins are not made or sold by Dakota artisans, which may raise concerns about their use of cultural products.

JC Penny scored a 0/19.5 for their cotton sourcing by WWF, but is also a founding member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition. They scored a 2.3/100 in the Corporate Information Transparency Index, which accounts for environmental supply chain practices in China, and a 15/100 in the 2020 Fashion Transparency Index. They scored a 17% on their management of sourcing conflict minerals in Congo. They are Responsible Down Standard certified, but they still use animal products like leather, cashmere and wool.

UNIQLO is rated a B- by the Ethical Fashion Guide, and has been identified as a company taking proper Covid-19 response measures. They scored a 40% on the Fashion Transparency Index, and are identified as a company using Uyghur forced labor in China. They have banned the use of angora, but still use animal products in their items. They offer a clothing recycling proogram at their stores, but do not provide transparent information about their environmental impacts or where they source their materials. They do not commit to paying a living wage to their workers.

Vans is rated a B by the Ethical Fashion Guide, and has been identified as a company taking proper Covid-19 response measures. They also scored a 59% on the Fashion Transpanrency index, which placed them in the top 10% tier. They use the Higg Index to measure their environmental performance with the Sustainable Apparel Coalition, and are a Better Cotton Initiative member. However, they do not show work to use eco-friendly materials in their supply chain. They additionally are a Leather Working Group member to ensure environmental best practices in their leather supply chain.

DC Shoes is owned by Boardriders. They scored a 9/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index which analyzes what they report in their supply chain. They are not transparent about their environmental practices and impacts. Ethical Fashion Guide has identified DC Shoes as a brand with no apparent Covid response for their company, and rates a C-. The company uses animal products like leather and does not publish any animal welfare policies. DC is not certified or verified by any 3rd party organizations.

Converse is a shoe and apparel company owned by Nike, Inc, which uses Uyghur slave labor, has several human rights violations, and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. They rely on production facilities in Cambodia that abuse their garment workers, and earned a 32% rating on Forest 500, and a D- on the Carbon Disclosure Project's rating. In 2019 they became a Responsible Minerals Initiative member, but scored a 46% on performance in sourcing minerals in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. They scored the lowest rating in Ethical Consumer for tax avoidance, and made a commitment to zero discharge of hazardous chemicals by 2020. Bluesign member. Does not use fur, but uses leather and wool, and is a member of the Working Leather Group that ensures compliance in tannery practices, however they do not have a clear animal welfare policy for their business practices. They became a core partner in 2019 for the Make Fashion Circular initiative, a Better Work partner in 2020 to improve working conditions in the garment industry. They also scored a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark, and a 100% for LGBT workplace equality. Converse scored 55% for the Fashion Transparency Index, scoring in the top 10 of 2020.

Marks & Spencer is a supermarket that is certified cruelty free by Cruelty Free International, and ranked highly on the 2019 Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare Report. They offer vegan and vegetarian products, however they do use animal products in their food, and leather and wool. In 2016, M&S were under investigation for using factories exploiting Syrian refugee children to make their clothing. In 2020, the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark scored them a 20.5 out of 26 (78.8%) for their supply chain practices, with at least one major investigation underway for sweatshop labor in Bangladesh. They transparently publish their Plan A reports on corporate performance, and a map of their supplier factories and raw materials on their website. They are also thoroughly audited through Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit. As for environmental impacts, they have partnered with WWF to commit to seafood sustainability.WWF also scores them an 18.8/22 as "leading the way" for the sustainable palm oil industry. They are a member of the Better Cotton Initiative, and as of 2020 produce about 1/3 of their cotton products with sustainable cotton. They also offer clothing drop-off with Oxfam called "Shwop", allowing the clothes to be donated or recycled.

Divine is a chocolatier committed to empowering women in Ghana and listed as using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. They are Non GMO Project certified, and do not use palm oil.
Tcho is listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and uses a portion of FairTrade ingredients.

Michaels arts & crafts is a member of Open to All, a national public education campaign against discrimination, and the Boys and Girls Clubs of America & Canada to support young people's' access to pathways to success. They score a 25/100 on CSRHub's Corporate Sustainability Report and report their 2020 Sustainability Report on their website. Over 45% of Michaels stores' waste was recycled in 2019. Michaels is Great Place to Work - Certified for 2019-2020. They have a charity "Michaels CARES" that helps employees with grants to recover from a difficult event such as a natural disaster or family loss. They also offer veteran employment, offer employees adoption benefits, tuition reimbursement, and discounts for veterans, senior, and teachers. Their sustainability measures including using LEED-certified light bulbs and offering toxic disposal for some of their products reflect minimal effort to compete with more sustainable corporate practices. They additionally lack transparency about where they source their animal products.
Ocho is a FairTrade Certified, Organic, Certified Vegan, and certified CCOF chocolate company.

They are listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. Their website transparently shows their 2019 Impact Report, and they are certified Organic and Fair For Life. They give their farmers a stable price to circumvent the volatility of the cocoa market, incentivising farmers to maintain a quality crop and support their families every year. They use dairy in their products, but offer vegan varieties.

Equal Exchange is a worker-owned cooperative that They are listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable.

Hanes scored a 41% on As You Sow's conflict mining report, suggesting minimal efforts to responsibly source minerals for their products in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. They scored a 23% on their 2019 Corporate Sustainability Assessment by S&P Global, which looks at their climate action plan, reporting and labor/human rights practices. They were rated an A- by Carbon Disclosure Project, and in 2016, Rank a Brand scored Hanes a 2/19.5 on their sustainable cotton sourcing and traceability. Hanes' CEO is paid 559 times the salary of the average worker, and exorbitant pay contributes to the rising inequality in work forces. Hanes scored a 39% on the Fashion Transparency index, which is above the average (23%), showing they are working to increase transparency in their supply chains. They also scored in the 50-60% range on the Human Rights Benchmark, well over the average of 24%, and have demonstrated efforts to combat forced labour and human trafficking in supply chains. It is unclear to what extent hanes uses animal products, but they have been recognized as being cruelty-free by crueltyfreeinvesting.org

Hormel ranks a tier 3 on the 2019 Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare, meaning the company established animal welfare policies but still need much work. In 2019, the CEO was paid 185 times the salary of the average-paid employee. They scored a 10/100 on the KnowTheChain Benchmark for addressing forced labor and human trafficking. They were rated F for their plastic pollution, and a 31% on the Forest 500 Benchmark. They scored a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark, and an 11/100 on their supply chain practices in China.

Lush specializes handmade cruelty-free, vegetarian products with minimal packaging. They are Fair Tax Mark Accredited which verifies Lush pays their taxes fairly and does not commit tax fraud or abuse. Their soap bases are palm-oil free, however they are transparent on their website about educating consumers about how some of their products have trace amounts of palm oil, and how to avoid it. Lush hosts annual competitions awarding researchers and campaigners who innovate ways to reduce animal testing and promote sustainability. Their "plastic" packaging is 100% biodegradable vegetable-based cellulose, and they have a recycling program that offers a free mask for every 5 containers returned to the store.

Fabletics is an athletic wear subscription service run by co-founder Kate Hudson, and CEO Adam Goldenberg who has been caught up in marketing settlements for deceptive advertising, and was accused by consumers for wrongful credit card charges. Goldenberg was also the CEO of "miracle weight-loss powder" Sensa. They are rate a 1.16/5 on the Better Business Bureau, with over 600 unresolved complaints. Some complaints entail unreliable call center hotline service, unpredictable quality, and wastefulness of the subscription suggesting hyperconsumption. They do not share information about whether their workers are paid a fair wage, if they use sweatshop labor, or where their materials are sourced. There is no evidence of paying their workers a living wage or if they use sustainable practices. They do not use animal products.

Industry of all Nations pays their workers a fair wage. Their products are not organized by gender, creating space for genderfluid shoppers. They use biodegradable natural dyes and do not bleach their apparel, and they are transparent on their website about where their indigo is farmed and how their process is less water-intensive. They use eco-friendly materials like organic cotton and agave fiber. They do use animal products and exotic furs. They offer repairs for their customers to reduce them going to the landfill, and urge their customers to buy only what they need and do not participate in sale events. They also offer information about their sourcing on their website to show where their products are made.

ColourPop is a cruelty-free cosmetics brand. They do sell vegan products, but not all of them are. They source their Mica in the US, Japan, and Europe. EWG's Skin Deep ratings for Colourpop Cosmetics range from 1 (best) to 5 (average) on a scale of 10 being the worst for ingredient concerns like cancer risk, allergies, and reproductive toxicity. They do not transparently offer information about whether their workers are paid a living wage, where they source their ingredients from, or if their supply chain involves prison labor or child labor. They also donated $25,000 to the Minnesota Freedom Fund, $25,000 to the ACLU, and $250,000 to Black communities through other organizations in June of 2020.

Steel Straws are a sustainable alternative to plastic straws that are extremely damaging to ocean wildlife and the environment. This straw company offers a sustainable reusable option. They do not use any animal products and are vegan. The straws are made from 100% recyclable stainless steel. They are members of 1% For the Planet and partner with multiple other organizations to support sustainability and social causes. They claim to have a formal track for supporting diversity in their supply chain but do not share it on their website.

Final straws are a sustainable alternative to plastic straws that are extremely damaging to ocean wildlife and the environment. This straw company offers a sustainable reusable option. They do not use any animal products and are vegan. The straws are made from platinum grade silicone, and the case is made from post-consumer recycled plastic.

Public Goods is a marketplace of minimalist unbranded household items. They offer student discounts and cheaper prices for higher quality goods. It is unclear what their labor practices and social practices are. Their containers are made from sugar cane bottles to avoid plastic pollution, and they sell tree-free paper products. They also plant a tree for every order placed. They are vegan-friendly, but not exclusively vegan.

Modern Citizen is a woman-owned business that ships in compostable and recycled packaging, and offsets their carbon with Cloverly, which is transparent on their website and has offset over 70,000 tonnes of carbon so far with their online store. They claim to have donated $10,000 to Feeding America's Covid-19 Response Fund in April of 2020, however their name does not come up on the Covid-19 Relief Fund site directory and it not verifiable. The brand uses animal products like leather, wool and exotic animal hair. They source their labor from Los Angeles and China, where there is a high-risk for labor violations. Modern Citizen is not otherwise transparent about where they source their materials, or if they pay their employees a living wage.

Ana Luisa is a jewelry that claims to use 100% recycled gold for their solid gold jewelry. They partner with Cool Effect Inc, a carbon offsetting non profit that rates a 75/100 on Charity Navigator. With Cool Effect, they have made their business carbon neutral with their offsets. They post their methodology for reducing their carbon footprint transparently on their website, and the company uses conflict-free lab-grown diamonds. It is not transparent however where their gold-plating is sourced from, whether they pay their employees a living wage, and how their supply chain operates. They do not use animal products in their jewelry.

Amber Cycle is small startup that upcycles end-of-life clothing. Instead of the traditional way of using PET pellets derived from oil to make polyester, they create PET pellets from clothing waste and regenerated pellets instead. This process has can potentially transform millions of tons of thrown out clothing into fresh material for textiles and preventing them from going into the landfill. They have also partnered with H&M to create this fiber.

Equal Exchange is a worker-owned cooperative that They are listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable.

Divine is a chocolatier committed to empowering women in Ghana and listed as using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. They are Non GMO Project certified, and do not use palm oil.

Justin's is Rainforest Alliance certified and Non GMO Project certified. They partner with the Xerces Society and People & Pollinators Action Network to support pollinator conservation. They are transparent with their palm oil sourcing practices on their website and uses either 100% Organic sustainable palm oil or RSPO certified palm oil. They use wind power in their manufacturing practices. Their peanut butter cups are FairTrade certified, but it is unclear if this is true for all of their products.
UnReal is a Non GMO Project certified chocolate and candy brand. They use FairTrade ingredients and sell mostly vegan products.

Tony's Chocolonely is listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and has a business model that prioritizes 0% profit in favor of using their revenue for greater impact in the field of slave-free chocolate. Their packaging is recyclable, and they offset their Carbon footprint through the JustDiggit project. Does use dairy in their chocolate.

Endangered Species chocolate scores an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. They donate 10% of profits to animals, habitat and humanity, and are Non GMO Project Verified. Their 2019 Impact Report is transparent and available publicly on their website where they share information about the conservation projects they partner with. They do not use palm oil. Endangered Species was listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate. Most of their chocolate is labeled certified vegan.

Alter Eco is an organic chocolatier listed as a brand using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, scores an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable, and are B Corp certified. They do not use palm oil in their products, and they use compostable packaging. They do use grass-fed milk in their products, but so sell some plant-based items. Their 2019 Sustainability Report is publicly available on their website.
Factory Direct Craft lacks transparency about how their employees are treated and paid, where they source their products from, their sustainability measures or their social involvement.

Cerer is a small clothing brand focused on sustainability. They are a 1% for the Planet member, and ships in recycled, zero-waste packaging. They do not disclose if their workers are treated fairly and if they are paid a living wage.

Dear Survivor is a small business dedicated to paying it forward to communities affected by sex trafficking. They donated over $20,000 to Generate Hope, an organization helping women rebuild their lives after trafficking. They use ethically sourced materials, and their leather and metal objects are made from scraps to give them a new life, and their items are ships in recyclable packaging.

Pact is a Fair Trade certified and Global Organic Textile Standard certified apparel brand. They use eco-friendly materials like organic cotton in their products, and they use wool. They host a donation program called "Give Back Box" that receives donated clothing to go to nonprofits that need them. Pact ships in minimal packaging and offers a Carbon neutral shipping option.

Sami Miro Vintage is a POC and woman-owned small business specializing in sustainable upcycled clothing. They do not use animal products in their line, and minimize waste by operating and sourcing locally in Los Angeles.

Come Back As A Flower, or CBAAF is a POC-owned small apparel business that uses 100% recycled cotton, and is based in Los Angeles where materials are sourced locally. It is not transparent whether their apparel is made in an ethical facility that pays a living wage. They do not use animal products.

Label By Three is a small POC-owned vegan clothing shop that sources locally and handmakes their apparel from deadstock fabrics that are upcycled into new clothing. They ship in 100% post-consumer and recyclable packaging, and they pay their employees a living wage.

Coach scored a 100% on the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index, a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark, a 28% in Forest 500 on their steps to eradicate deforestation in their practices, a 19/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and a 21/100 by S&P Global for their corporate sustainability. Coach's CEO is paid 486 times the median employee wage. They were also rated a D on the Carbon Disclosure Project, who score their disclosure, awareness, management, and leadership in response to reducing climate change in their supply chain. Coach additionally scored a 0/19.5 in their traceability of sourcing sustainable cotton by Rank a Brand. In 2020, they scored a 5.4/100 on their environmental management and water pollution in Chinese supply chains. In 2018, numerous labor law violations were found in their main factory in China. They are a partner of the Leather Working Group that ensures compliance and sustainability in their tannery practices, and are a Sustainable Apparel Coalition member. In 2019, As You Sow scored Coach's conflict mineral mining practices at a 50%, which is an adequate score for the industry.

The Doggy Treat is a family-owned, Black-owned business specializing in USA-made dog treats. They ship in compostable and recyclable packaging. Sources of their ingredients fluctuate but mainly come from Hormel.

Ali Express is owned by their sister company, Alibaba (2.3). They have been accused of credit card fraud, counterfeit products and missing items, which cannot be traced because the sellers remain anonymous. Their low transparency makes it difficult to understand from an ethical perspective, however it is widely acknowledged that the company is comparable to Amazon and exploits laborers by promoting excessive overtime culture in favor of corporate revenue.

Cuddle Clones is a pet-focused, hand-made plush shop that donates to animal welfare shelters and organizations, and provides 3 meals and a toy to a shelter pet with every purchase. These organizations are listed on their website and are traceable. The plushes are made in Chinaâs Guangdong province at a 100%-owned small workshop, where they are in close proximity to local materials they source, mainly polyester and acrylic, and the shop claims to source only synthetic materials. They do not disclose their sustainability measures or if they pay a living wage, and the only information available is on their website, which is not third-party certified.

Michaels arts & crafts is a member of Open to All, a national public education campaign against discrimination, and the Boys and Girls Clubs of America & Canada to support young people's'  access to pathways to success. They score a 25/100 on CSRHub's Corporate Sustainability Report and report their 2020 Sustainability Report on their website. Over 45% of Michaels stores' waste was recycled in 2019. Michaels is Great Place to Work - Certified for 2019-2020. They have a charity "Michaels CARES" that helps employees with grants to recover from a difficult event such as a natural disaster or family loss. They also offer veteran employment, offer employee adoption benefits, tuition reimbursement, and discounts for veterans, senior, and teachers. Their sustainability measures including using LEED-certified light bulbs and offering toxic disposal for some of their products reflect minimal effort to compete with more sustainable corporate practices. They additionally lack transparency about where they source their animal products.

Hobby Lobby is a corporate arts and crafts retailer. They are well known for their supreme court case Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc. which allows closely held corporations to restrict resources on employees' medical insurance that conflict with the employer's religious beliefs. Hobby Lobby requires its employees to sign a binding arbitration agreement that waves the employees' right to bring workplace violations and disputes to court. In 2017, legal action was taken by employees to sue Hobby Lobby to pay back uncompensated overtime wages. Transparency is lacking in their environmental and animal welfare practices, and there is no Corporate Sustainability Report ranking due to lack of data available. They are additionally not third party certified by organizations that monitor their labor and sustainability claims. Hobby Lobby was charged for illegally importing ancient artifacts for their "Museum of the Bible" exhibit, in which they paid a fine of $3 million and the artifacts were later returned to Iraq.

Whole Foods is a globalized organic food retailer bought out by Amazon in 2017. Despite landing on Ethisphere's "World's Most Ethical Companies" Honoree list in previous years for their sustainability and "conscious corporate" demeanor, they did not make the list for the 2020-2021 year. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Indonesian rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Whole Foods scored a sustainable palm oil source rating from WWF of 8/22, which is poor, which conflicts with their website statement claiming 100% of their palm oil is sustainably harvested through RSPO. Recent lawsuit include claims of employee retaliation and selective enforcement for masks with anti-racism messages, a federal class-action lawsuit for withholding employee bonuses to maximize profit, and unlawfully collecting employee fingerprints. The retailer was criticized in 2019 for cutting hours on a mass scale after pressure to raise their hourly wage to $15, defeating the purpose of paying a living wage. Oxfam's "Behind the Barcode" initiative rated Whole Foods an 8% for their policies and practices in their labor rights in supply chains, and the company scored a 76% on their 2019 Corporate Sustainability Report. Their meat is Global Animal Partnership certified.

Whimsy + Row is a small business of 10 employees that uses recycled, biodegradable and eco-friendly fabrics, environmentally friendly packaging, and conserves water in their supply chain. They use silk and leather in their products. Whimsy + Row makes their clothing locally. They have also taken steps to incorporate anti-racism in their supply chain.

Dieux Skin is small business praised for its reusable, vegan & cruelty-free alternative to single-use eye masks. They ship in reusable and recyclable packaging, and keep their containers light and larger to reduce the Carbon impact of refills. They donate to organizations like Fair Fight to support voter re-enfranchisement, and are a Floret Coalition member that supports anti-racism in the Cannabinoid industry. They are transparent about their prices, materials and practices.

Bite toothpaste bits are plastic-free, cruelty-free and vegan. They ship in a refillable glass bottle, and recycled compostable post-consumer material. They offer refills shipped in compostable packages, which are lightweight as opposed to heavier glass refills. Little information is publicly available regarding their labor practices of social involvement.

Flamingos Life is a vegan, biodegradable sneaker store that operates and sources locally in Spain. Their shoes are made using materials like corn waste, bamboo, hemp, organic cotton, and sustainably extracted natural rubber. They also partner with other nonprofits to support clean ocean, water access and reforestation projects. They are also a BCOME member, which requires textile and apparel businesses to build efficient, sustainable and transparent supply chains under safe and ethical working conditions.

The Children's place lacks public transparency in their practices, and likewise scored a 9/100 by the 2020 Fashion Transparency Index. In 2019, the CEO was paid 1262 times the amount of a median employee, while the company furloughed a majority of their workforce for the Covid-19 pandemic. They source from countries with high labor violation risk, including the Rana Plaza factory in Bangladesh that collapsed in 2013 and killed at least 1,134 workers. They became a Better Cotton Initiative member in 2019, and a member of the Bangladesh Worker Safety Alliance in 2020. They also are a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and AFIRM group. They do not use any animal products.

B. Yellowtail is an artisan collective that celebrates Indigenous storytelling through wearable fashion. They are Native-owned and operated on Native land in North America, and employ with First Nations models, photographers, and poets to design and market their handmade clothing. They fundraised $6000 for the No-DAPL and women's' rights movements. They make their items b traditional sustainable means and use deadstock fabrics, which are reused second-hand to reduce waste and carbon impact. B. Yellowtail also partners with the Decolonizing Wealth Project to donate masks to Tribal communities who have been devastated by Covid-19. They use leather and decorative feathers in their items.

GLDN is a Washington handmade jewelry workshop praised for its customizable and size-inclusive jewelry. They donate 10% of their profits in their Giving Back program, have collections that donate up to 100% of the profits to organizations they partner with and show on their website, and pay their employees for 10 hours of volunteer work. 95% of GLDN's materials are sourced domestically, and 90% of the metals they use are recycled, meaning they do not mine new gold, rather they buy second-hand, which reduces the environmental impact of mining. Their pacing uses recycled materials, their items are made to order, and they recycle all of their scrap metals to prevent waste. Their materials do not involve any animal products. They do not include information about where exactly their 10% of non-recycled metals come from.

Pacsun lacks transparency in several factors such as where their materials are sourced, if they pay a living wage to their workers, and where their leather and wool are sourced from. They do have a sustainable eco-friendly collection called "Me to We," however it is unclear where these materials are sourced and how the workers on this line are treated as well. They claim to have a Conflict Minerals Report on their website, however the link leads nowhere and a current report cannot be found with a basic search engine. Pacsun is also not third-party certified by any organizations, meaning they aren't held accountable for the claims they make about labor practices and sustainability.
Fenty does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.

Fenty Beauty is a skincare brand praised for its products' skin tone diversity in the cosmetics industry. They do not test on animals, and sell refillable packaging, and ship in recycled and post-consumer materials. Fenty lacks transparency in their environmental impacts, labor practices and wage pay, and social involvement.

Il Makiage does not test on animals. The company also sells the idea of maximalism to shoppers, and  ships in packaging with bold text "Minimalism is dead" and "there's no such thing as too much", encouraging hyper-consumption. Il Makiage lacks transparency about their environmental practices, product sourcing, and social involvement.

Tomboyx sells underwear and apparel to people of all genders. They avoid most animal products except they do use wool. They operate in Oeko-tex 100 certified factories, which recycle at least 50% of their water use and pay their employees a living wage. They have a line of apparel made from MicroModal fabric which uses sustainably harvested Beechwood. Tomboyx appreciates diversity in their models, and is a seize-inclusive brand (XS-4X). They also have donated to several social justice initiatives like Black Lives Matter, ACLU, and Trans Women of Color Collective.

Joann fabrics store is a member of the Corporate Giving program, in which they donate a portion of their proceeds to nonprofits such as the Kids In Need Foundation, and donated 300 million masks for those in need. Joanne uses some animal products like silk, and does not share where their materials are sourced from. They also lack transparency in their environmental impact and labor practices.

Human Kind is a bath & body brand focusing on zero-waste, ships in carbon-neutral packaging, and offsets their carbon impact with funding reforestation projects in Brazil and New Jersey. All of their products are cruelty-free, and all products except for their silk floss are vegan. They supply their palm oil from RSPO-certified and Fair-Trade certified manufacturers. Human Kind lacks transparency about their labor practices, and little information is available about their social involvement.

Thinx sells reusable menstrual cycle underwear, which creates a sustainable and environmentally friendly option opposed to single-use period products. Thinx recently came under fire for their poor workplace culture and sexual harassment claims against the CEO, but is now run under different ownership. The current Thinx company still lacks transparency about their labor practices, and fails to provide evidence that they source from ethical facilities free of labor rights violations. They do not use animal products. The crotch area of their panties recently tested positive for toxic chemicals, particularly PFAS, which even at very low levels is linked to cancer and fertility problems due to the absorbent nature of vaginal tissue. This is also problematic because Thinx claimed their underwear did not contain these toxins in their products. They do donate to other social rights organizations like the EveryBody program, but do not appear to be third-party certified to support their claims.
Pela products are compostable and ship in plastic-free packaging. They're Climate Neutral certified, and donate to 1% for the Planet. They do not use animal products.

Multiplicity is a woman-owned business, and is run on their own with only one employee and founder. The clothing is made-to-order, which prevents fabric waste and promotes slow-fashion. She uses Econyl, a type of recycled fiber made from nylon, and does not use animal products.

Boka's products are vegan, not tested on animals, BPA-free, and made in the USA, Italy, and China. With every purchase, Boka partners with Surge, a water crisis and sanitation non-profit, to donate toothbrushes to people in need. They do not provide transparent information online about if their practices are eco-friendly or labor-friendly.

Womn is a woman-owned, POC-owned, slow-fashion business that focuses on made-to-order clothes that are durable to prevent fashion waste, with recycled and natural fibers like organic cotton, tincel, and bamboo. Their facility is in Los Angeles, CA, and they are a vegan brand. WOMN claims their facilities are ethically certified but failed to transparently show which certifications those are. They ship in recycled and recyclable polyethylene bags. Unfortunately WOMN will be shutting down as of October 2, 2020.

Ocean Spray has been identified by the Sustainable Agriculture Initiative Platform in 2020 as the first major food company in the US to be certified 100% sustainable for their water conservation practices and using the whole cranberry to prevent excessive food waste. They do not use palm oil or BPA in their products. They are recognized by the Human Rights Campaign for their LGBT equality, and are a Social Accountability International member being held accountable for their working conditions and labor practices. Ocean spray includes a clear label with recycling instructions to consumers, which can help reduce plastic waste from the landfill. Ocean Spray did settle a $5.4 million class action lawsuit in June of 2020 for false advertisement that they did not use artificial flavors in some of their juices. Note: If cranberries are not grown organically, they are detrimental to waterways due to the heavy pesticide and fertilizer use sprayed into the bogs they are grown in. Luckily, Ocean Spray does sell some organic cranberry juices, however their usual products contribute to this issue.

Tradlands makes claims of sustainability and eco-friendliness, but lacks transparency in how they do it. They pride their items on their long-lasting material, which if true does add to their sustainability and anti-fast fashion, however failing to provide this information has been interpreted by some as a form of greenwashing. The company is also not third party certified, so the claims they make cannot be held accountable.

Vetta is a high-end, slow fashion capsule wardrobe brand that encourages shoppers to choose 5 items to mix-and-match to create 30 outfits per month. They source sustainable materials like organic cotton, package shipments in 100% recycled materials, and use 70% solar power in their eco-friendly USA factories. Vetta does not use animal products, and are certified with SA8000 (for factories in India), the Global Organic Textile Standard and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA). There are no observable praises or concerns over their social ethics.

Bare Soaps uses a sustainable business model that centers around economic, social, and environmental accountability. They use Rainforest Alliance certified palm oil, recycled/recyclable materials, compostable and plantable packaging, and are no-waste, except for the plastic lids on their mud masks. They offset the Carbon of every shipment with reforestation projects, and their ingredients are vegan except for their Jubilee Jam soap that contains goat milk. In 2016, they partnered with the Sundara Fund to repurpose used hotel soaps and employ women in India with 3x the minimum wage to supply antiseptic resources to children. The woman-owned and POC-owned business is run by a single person, and 20% of their proceeds are reinvested into their economic development programs in India and Uganda.

Nestle has a notorious reputation for being one of the most corrupt corporations in the world, and is the target of the worlds longest running boycott. Nestle continuously breaches international marketing standards, most notably in their targeting of pregnant and breastfeeding women in which they spread false information and gave women in underserved communities week supplies of baby formula (enough to induce the termination of breastmilk production) so that the women were forced to buy more of Nestle's formula after their breasts no longer produced milk by the time the free supply was used. Nestle attempts to stake claim to community water resources across North America, destroying streams, aquifers and wildlife. They are the world's 3rd most plastic polluter, are responsible for mass deforestation for cocoa and palm oil use which destroys the Orangutan habitat. They are one of the worst perpetrators of human rights violations including failing to stop child labor in their cocoa fields, and Brazilian slave labor on their cocoa plantations. They scored an 11.8/100 on their supply chain practices in China. Nestle does test on animals. They also undermine local control of water supplies in communities, then promote sales of bottled water there to turn a profit, and have shown no evidence of addressing the findings of nanoparticles in their baby formula, which can bioaccumulate in children from infancy and pose a threat to human health. Additionally, Nestle grossly violated human rights and experiment laws by testing their baby formula on 75 premature babies in India. In 2015, Nestle rejected Baby Milk Action's 4-point plan (submitted in 2001) to address the boycott filed against them for their treatment of breastfeeding women and causing countless infant deaths. They also pay only $200/year to pump fresh water out of Flint, Michigan while it's citizens still have no access to clean water.

Parade underwear are made in Oeko-Tex certified and Sedex certified factories in China. Their products ship in minimal, compostable packaging. Their products are made of pre-consumer recycled nylon, and comply with the Global Recycled Standard. They have donated $12,000 to Planned Parenthood New York, and the Yellowhammer Fund in Alabama. They are also size inclusive (XS - 3XL), and are working to expand their sizes further. Parade's models are diverse, and they do not use animal products in their items.

Valfre donated $15,000 to the NAACP legal defense fund, are a Latina-owned business, and donated 10% of Earth Day sales to the Nature Conservancy. However, their transparency is not so great regarding where they source their materials. they also have an activist tee section which gives proceeds to various charities. They do not test on animals.

Confidence Swimwear is a size-inclusive (sizes 0-20) swimwear brand that uses eco-friendly materials like regenerated Nylon made from ocean-bound plastic bottles and fishing nets. They use their spare material to make masks so that it doesn't go to waste. Their Balinese tailors are paid above minimum wage, and work from the comfort of home with their own hours. These are progressive claims, however this information is only available on their website and not third-party certified.

Reveal plants a tree for every product sold on their website, which has donated over $110,000 dollars to American Forests and other non-profits. They made their products from eco-friendly materials like bamboo, cork, cruelty-free vegan leather, and post-consumer plastic bottles.

Samsung uses Uyghur Muslim slave labor, and scores within the 30-40% range on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. Samsung scored a 20.3/100 on the conflict minerals ranking, which scores a companies effort in responsibly mining from the Democratic Republic of the Congo.They received a D rating in ClickClean, which scores a companies online energy footprint. Their efforts to eliminate child labor practices in their manufacturing processes were weak. The repairability of their devices is also low, making it difficult for low-income communities to maintain access to their electronic goods.

Wayfair lacks transparency in their practices. They have an Environmental, Social and Governance score of 2, which is below average. Wayfair has recently been criticized for doing business with migrant detention camps. They have also been criticized for lacking corporate ethics implementation strategies in their supply chain.

About 40% of West Elm's product line is Fair-Trade Certified as of 2020, and uses engineered or reclaimed wood which is more energetically efficient and sustainable. They use animal products like sheepskin and leather in their products. According to EndSlaveryNow, West Elm is a safe retailer of slavery-free products.

Although Ulta is a cosmetic marketplace for many brands, this score reflects the practices of the company itself. Ulta's collection does not test on animals. Ulta has been accused of racial profiling and forcing employees to resell used cosmetics to shoppers.

Although Sephora is a cosmetic marketplace for many brands, this score reflects the practices of the company itself. Sephora's cosmetic brand is not cruelty-free, although they do sell cruelty-free and vegan cosmetics. Many cosmetic brands source Mica, a mineral used in most shimmery cosmetics, using child labor. Most of Sephora's brands source their mica from these quarries, except for the brand Aether Beauty, which claims to use fair-trade Mica from France. Sephora claims to put sustainability "front and center," but reputable data is lacking in transparency.

Shein is a fast-fashion giant that does not share information about their business practices online, as their transparency is severely lacking. Fast-fashion brands rely on sweatshops using unsafe working conditions and child labor to make their prices lower, and do to their low-quality nature and high micro-seasonality contribute to being the second most polluting industry in the world.

Best Buy uses an extensive free e-waste recycling program, with 85% waste diversion in 2020, and was named one of the Ethisphere's World's Most Ethical Companies list. They were also featured on the Climate Change A List, as a leading company on environmental transparency and performance. The company's Geek Squad also works with the FBI to report child sexual abuse found on computers taken in for repair.

Aldi scores a 30% by Forest 500, an organization that analyzes rainforest risk-management in company supply chains. Aldi's hen suppliers for eggs have densities of over 10,000 hens/hectare, almost 7x the maximum of free-range requirements. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Aldi scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 18.3/22, which is above average. Their Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare rating is a tier 2, meaning Aldi seeing animal welfare as "Integral to business strategy." They also scored a B- in the Ethical Fashion Report, which measures labor violations.

McDonald's was scored a 24% for their animal welfare practices by World Animal Protection. They have had multiple labor rights violation lawsuits and racial discrimination, and were scored in the 20-30% range by the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, McDonald's scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 13.8/22, which is below average.

Costco scored a 15/100 on 2020's Fashion Transparency Index, and a 0-10% range score on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They got a "red" rating for their tuna sourcing which means the company fails to sustainably source tuna in a way that allows populations to rebound the next harvest season. Costco received an F rating for their paper tissue sourcing by Natural Resources Defense Council and Stand.earth, a 16.6/100 by Greenpeace for failing to address the plastic pollution crisis in their manufacturing processes, and ranked as one of the world's worst plastic polluters in 2018. Costco has been identified as a company using Uyghur forced labor in China. Costco received a score of 7.5/120 for their rating on failing to develop a conflict-free mining process in the Congo. They also received an 18/100 on the Corporate Sustainability Assessment, a 27/100 with Forest 500, and received a D rating from the Carbon Disclosure Project, an initiative that asks brands to disclose how they are taking measures to mitigate climate change risk. Costco received a 23/100 on their efforts to address forced labour and human trafficking in their supply chains, and have recently dropped Chaokoh, a coconut brand, after they were found to use exploitative monkey labor in their sourcing.

Ebay scored an A- on the Carbon Disclosure Project, an initiative that asks brands to disclose how they are taking measures to mitigate climate change risk. They scored a B at ClickClean.org, which analyzes the energy footprint of companies' online presence and encourages this to be sourced from renewable energy. Ebay also scored a 100% on the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index, and scored 63/100 on the 2019 SAM Corporate Sustainability Assessment. In contrast, Ebay was found to likely use  tax avoidance strategies with the worst rating by Ethical Consumer, and Ebay's CEO, Devin Wenig, was ranked #88 on USA's most overpaid CEOs. CEO overpayment negatively affects the companies, employes, customers, economy, and society.

TJ Maxx scored a 15/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and sources their materials from sweatshops that pay their workers only $4/hour. They scored a 90% on the the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index.

Seven & I scored a 10/100 on the Forest 500 report., a 10-20% on the Human Rights Benchmark, and a 28.9% on the Newsweek Green Ranking. They also scored the lowest ranking for their animal welfare practices on the 2019 Business Benchmark.

Alibaba's low transparency makes it difficult to understand from an ethical perspective, however it is widely acknowledged that the company is comparable to Amazon and exploits laborers by promoting excessive overtime culture in favor of corporate revenue.

Lowe's has a 2.4/5 rating for labor reviews, and ignited controversy by pulling ads from 'All-American Muslim' program. They are incorporating "Smart Irrigation" technology and taking sustainability measures in their store energy use.

The Home Depot's plastic supplier is being sued over using unpaid, forced inmate labor. In May of 2020, forest protectors protested The Home Depot and FSC logging and herbicide application at Rainbow Ridge, a high conservation value forest. (Not included in the score but may be good to know: boycotts have been formed against The Home Depot for their co-founder's support and donating to the Trump 2020 campaign, and $7 million to Trump's 2016 presidential run).
