Mango scored a 5/100 on the Corporate Information Transparency Index which analyzes supply chain practices. They scored a 22/100 in the Fashion Transparency Index as well. In 2019, the signed onto the Bangladesh Safety Accord to support worker safety and labor rights. They use some eco-friendly materials like organic cotton.

Boohoo fails to pay minimum living wage to workers, and scored a 9/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index. They have been criticized for misleading advertising in which they claimed a jumper was faux fur, but tested and discovered to be from real animal fur. received a C- grade in the Ethical Fashion Report.

Sears has very low transparency about their business practices. They have released some environmental reports, however in light of their bankruptcy and closing it is difficult to know for sure what their practices are like this year.

Matt & Nat are well known for their vegan handbags, in which they use recycled nylon, cork, rubber, plastic bottles and bike tires. However, the most commonly used materials used are polyurethane and polyvinyl chloride, or PVC, one of the most environmentally harmful plastics as well as high-risk to workers manufacturing with it. Matt & Nat has also been criticized for exaggerating their green claims. They are SA800-certified for their labor practices, but show little transparency about how these policies are enforced, and how their manufacturing process occurs.

Carrefour scored a 20/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and does not provide much information about its ethical practices. It also scored a 25/100 on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They additionally scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 12.8/22. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat.

Thrive Market is Global Animal Partnership certified, offers fast and free Carbon-neutral shipping and free membership to veterans, students, and struggling families. Their warehouses are zero-waste, and the company offers a variety of vegan and cruelty-free products. The Thrive Market COVID-19 Relief Fund raised $90,000 in donations.

Apple received an A rating on Greenpeace's Click Clean report, which monitors the environmental impact of its websites and apps. They also received an A rating for the Carbon Disclosure Project which analyzes how they disclose climate change risks in their practices, and are a Green Power Partner with the EPA. Scored a 5/7 in preventative child labor practices. Apple has been identified as using best corporate practices for LGBT equality by the Human Rights Campaign. That being said, Apple also has been found to use Uyghur slave labor, and expose its workers to benzene, a carcinogen. Since then Benzene has been banned in its supply chain, but not in subcontracting positions that make up 2/3 of it's manufacturing. Apple has been identified in 2019 as a company assisting the Burmese military to commit human rights violations and environmental destruction against its people, and Apple supports apps for companies the Burmese military owns, such as Mytel. Apple's low repairability capability makes it difficult for users to afford repair, and makes it harder for marginalized communities to have access to their devices in favor of revenue earned from forcing users to buy a new product when something goes wrong, which also adds to e-waste. Apple was also identified as high-risk for tax avoidance. Identified as not exploiting animals, but still uses leather for its wristbands and watches.

Starbucks is using renewable energy for 105% of its electricity use and has been identified as using best corporate practices for LGBT equality by the Human Rights Campaign. They are World Cocoa Foundation members committed to supporting sustainable cocoa sourcing, and Sustainable Agriculture Initiative members. Despite this, Starbucks scored an F in its 2019 Mind the Store report on using toxic chemicals from its consumer products, was rated in the 0-10% range for their Human Rights Benchmark, and were given a score of 15/100 on their supply chain practices in China. Starbucks also scored a 25/100 on the Forest 500 report, which checks for how their sourcing affects tropical rainforests, and were ranked as one of the world's worst plastic polluters. Starbucks also gets an F rating for their animal antibiotics use by the Natural Resources Defense Council, and fails to implement animal welfare implementation. Lastly, Starbucks has been titled as one of the worst tax-avoidance companies by Ethical Consumer.

Nordstrom scored a 67/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index. They have been criticized to still be selling fur coats when most department stores have phased out of this practice. In December of 2019, PETA released an exposÃ© of Nordstrom's sourcing from the Russian fur trade, in which the involved animals are abused and their regulations violated. Has made sustainability goals to reduce single-use plastic by 2025, but some of the other goals are non-quantitative and somewhat vague.

As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. They use leather, wool and exotic animal hair, but not down, angora or exotic animal skin.They scored a 35/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which is slightly above average. Claims to use eco-conscious materials such as Global Organic Textile Standard certified linen, hemp, cotton, Global Recycle Standard certified cotton, waterless-processed denim, and recycled knitwear. They operate in production in facilities running on 100% renewable energies and source from Fair Trade certified organizations.

Although it is virtually impossible to rate particular shops on Etsy, we can assess their practices. Etsy gives clear rules to sellers: No Child or Youth Labor, No Involuntary or Slave Labor, Humane Working Conditions, and Non-Discrimination. However, regulation of these rules are not constant. In 2020, Etsy failed to remove the influx of shops selling handmade mesh masks that falsely advertised to protect shoppers from COVID-19, and Etsy may have caused risk to public health by failing to do so. Additionally, Etsy has partnered with 3Degrees to combat climate change by offsetting the Carbon footprint of their shipping packages. All in all, Etsy may be a better alternative to corporations that fail to pay their workers fairly as most Etsy shops are self-made goods, but the environmental cost of shipping, and the types of materials used in each product can affect its ethical impact. Exercise caution when perusing Etsy, and if you'd like our input on a specific product, please send us an email!

American Eagle Outfitters scored a 17/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which was below the average of 23%. They scored a 25% on their Green Supply Chain report, which evaluates their environmental supply chain practices in China. For their 2019 SAM Corporate Sustainability Assessment, AEO scored a 10/100, showing much work to be done in the way of their risk-management for sustainability and labor practices. Better Cotton Initiative member, Better Work partner, and Fashion Industry Charter for Climate Action signatory. American Eagle Outfitters use leather, down and exotic animal hair, and have banned their use of angora, fur, and exotic animal skin.

Urban Outfitters have been criticized for selling extremely distasteful shirts, such as a blood-stained Kent State shirt, shirts for kids that advocate alcohol consumption, holocaust-style tapestries, and color options titled "Obama/black". As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. They do not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal hair, but they do use untraceable leather and wool. Although they have an upcycled clothing line, their main line does not use adequately sustainable materials. They also show little transparency (a 20% on the Fashion Transparency Index) and regarding their use of water and wastewater management. Additionally, their labor laws are often violated, most notably a scandal in which employees were asked to work for free for "training."

Wish's cheap prices reflect the underpaid labor (and sometimes child labor) it takes to offer such low prices. Wish's marketplace sources from third-party distributors in China, where although labor laws are in place, they are often over-sought in favor of revenue from mass-sales. This also allows Wish to not be held accountable for any violations the occur from the products' production.

Anthropologie rates a 0-10% on the 2019 Fashion Transparency Index, resulting from their lack of animal welfare policy and evidence that their supply chain operates in any ethical manner. They lack third party verification in their labor standards or living-wage practices. As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. Anthropologie has also been accused of racial profiling by salespeople, and not paying Black content creator Lydia Okello for their work.

Made Trade is a woman and POC-owned marketplace of hand-selected ethical products that are: Sustainable (Made with earth-friendly materials that are responsibly harvested or upcycled); Fair trade (Handmade by artisans adhering to fair labor practices); Heritage (Crafted by hand using traditional techniques); USA-Made: (Made by U.S. makers, but does not negate the possibility of in-country labor abuse); and Vegan (Free of animal materials and animal byproducts). They donate to 1% for the Planet, and have a Carbon-Neutral checkout process.

Wolven uses eco-friendly, locally sourced materials to make activewear from recycled water bottles and modal (a type of fiber from beachwood pulp). Partners with Cancel Plastic, who hire collectors to source ocean-bound plastic water bottles from polluted areas of Port-Au-Prince, Haiti. Wolven are currently committing 10% of net profits to the COVID-19 LA County Response Fund.

Pink is progressing their sustainability initiatives, is a Better Cotton Initiative member, a member of the JED foundation for teen mental health, donated $50k to the Human RIghts Campaign, $200k to the Feeding America Foundation, and $1 million to the National Urban League. HiBar is a cruelty-free and vegan company that uses eco-friendly packaging, compostable/recyclable packaging, and does not use palm oil. Their bars are biodegradable. They are also Carbon-neutral through partnership with the Southern Plains Land Trust.

Blueland has a strong environmental mission, platinum material health certificate from Cradle to Cradle, sells no-waste and no-plastic packaging, vegan and cruelty-free, and is leaping-bunny certified. They use glass to reduce plastic waste, but glass can be environmentally costly to transport. Their vendors are in compliance with the Business Social Compliance Initiative (BSCI), and they are in process of B Corp certification. Blueland pays employees for political and civic engagement and requires implicit bias training for new hires.

The NBA Store is taking measures for sustainability and upcycling of unsold jerseys into 7,000 masks, are a member of the Green Sports Alliance, have a code of conduct for labor practices publicly available, and won the Community Assist Award for 2019. However they have very low transparency. They have a line of recycled jerseys from plastics, but these often contribute to microplastics in the ocean. They are additionally in the process of transitioning to vegan/vegetarian foods at games and players are going vegan/vegetarian to help divest from animal agriculture. NBA jerseys are made by Adidas, who we score a 6.0.

LL Bean uses Uyghur slave labor, scores a 6/100 on transparency, are compliant with Responsible Down Standard (RDS), part of the Bangladesh Worker Safety Alliance, a Sustainable Apparel Coalition member, a Textile Exchange member, a BlueSign partner, but has low transparency about social welfare.

Spectrum Boutique is woman-owned, body-inclusive, gender non-conforming, and advocates for sex-education.

Innisfree uses an eco-recycling program for empty containers to be upcycled into other merchandise. They participate in the Eco-Handkerchief Campaign, which gifts hankies with purchase, but are not cruelty-free.

FashionNova is a Fast-fashion company, and uses Los Angeles sweatshops to make their clothing which disenfranchises workers. They contribute to over 92 million tons of clothing into the landfill annually, and have numerous labor violations. They do have a vegan collection for those who wish to avoid animal products.

Titleist makes their products in their factory in the USA. Golf balls last basically forever as opposed to single-use golf balls, but aren't biodegradable and often get lost outdoors. Titleist does not use animal products but there is little information on this, and golf balls adversely affect wildlife when lost.
BLK+GRN uses sustainable eco-packaging, are Black-owned social advocates and engage in activism, are a cruelty-free, plant-based, small business, and platforms artisans who have ethical practices.

Macy's has a low human rights benchmark rating, and a Fashion Transparency Index score of 16/100. The Macy's Day Parade is unsustainable with reckless Helium use. They are making strides in corporate solar panel energy usage, working on diversification, and will stop selling and storing fur by 2021. Macy's also has a GoFundMe "shop for a cause" charity.

Jolyn is slow-fashion, uses sustainable fabric, made in USA (yet source of labor TBD), partners with local charities, vegan, and fibers include no animal-based by-products. Petsmart has been responsible for many animal deaths at the hands of groomers and exotic animal trade and has poor labour conditions. They do fund a foundation for support-animals for people with disability.

Gamestop incorporated customer trickery in their practices to make money and has a few labor lawsuits filed against them. They do however have a good game recycling/upcycling program to prevent used games from going into the landfill.
Nintendo uses Uyghur child labor, has poor e-recycling practices, and scored a low labor rights ranking.
Vibram uses sustainable soles in their shoes, are vegan friendly, and removed from sales from Amazon.

Everlane appears to greenwash many of their products, as they scored a 30/100 on Remake's Sustainable Brand criteria. They claim to be transparent but fail to explain their wages paid to workers and their raw material sourcing. They lack certifications proving they pay fair wages, and source from countries that are high-risk for labor abuse. They do however make their denim jeans at Sai-Tex, one of the most sustainable denim factories in the world, yet the rest of their clothing is unaccounted for. They do make their "sustainable" clothing accessible by having lower prices, and advocate to go "no new plastic" by 2021 but not plastic-free. Everlane Donated 100% profits from Black Friday to environmental organization Oceana, and their leather is audited by the Leather Working Group. Everlane uses animal products (leather, wool, exotic animal hair). Their lack of third-party verification means they aren't held accountable with the claims they make. Everlane was also accused legitimately of union busting, where they laid off most workers who tried to unionize for Covid. Their "radical transparency" claim is more akin to "convenient transparency", and they are accused of anti-Black toxic workplace behavior.

Adidas uses Uyghur slave labor and fail to pay minimum living wage to workers. In 2019, they received an A rating in the Ethical Fashion Report, a 92/100 in the KnowTheChain Benchmark, but a 24% in the Human Rights Benchmark. They did score a 69% (above average, since the highest score was 73%) in the Fashion Transparency Index, signifying that Adidas publishes highly detailed supplier lists and policies. Adidas received a B rating for the Carbon Disclosure Project's analysis. Scored 2nd place in the 2020 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations in the World list, but simultaneously scored a 27% for the Forest 500 ranking for their timber use. They have also contributed to worker abuse issues in Cambodia by relying on their factories for their supply chain. They ban angora use, and are a Leather Working Group member. They also are a program member of the Make Fashion Circular initiative.

Nike uses Uyghur slave labor, has several human rights violations, and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. They rely on production facilities in Cambodia that abuse their garment workers. Earned a 32% rating on Forest 500, a D- on the Carbon Disclosure Project's rating. In 2019 they became a Responsible Minerals Initiative member, but scored a 46% on performance in sourcing minerals in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Scored the lowest rating in Ethical Consumer's tax avoidance. Made a commitment to zero discharge of hazardous chemicals by 2020. Bluesign member. Does not use fur, and is a member of the Working Leather Group that ensures compliance in tannery practices, however they do not have a clear animal welfare policy for their business practices. Became a core partner in 2019 for the Make Fashion Circular initiative. Became a Better Work partner in 2020 to improve working conditions in the garment industry. Scored a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark. They also scored a 100% for LGBT workplace equality. Nike started the N7 fund, which supports Native athletes with a line of clothing and shoes, which support athletic programs for Native and Indigenous youth.

Lululemon rates a 13/100 on the Global ESG score that measures sustainability practices, and a 24% on the 2019 Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They are a BlueSign member, Leaping Bunny Certified, fur-free, and uses RDS-certified down. Lululemon has been sourcing clothing from a factory in Bangladesh where women regularly experience physical violence, humiliation, and other abuses from their managers.Sustainable Apparel Coalition and Textile Exchange member working on reducing Lululemon's environmental and social impact. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

Forever 21 has been guilty of widespread labor violations in Los Angeles Fashion District sweatshops.They scored a 7/100 in the Fashion Transparency Index, and were found to irresponsibly source rayon, viscose, and other tree-based fabrics for their apparel. Forever 21 received an D- rating in Ethical Fashion Report and have banned the use of fur and Angora in their production. They additionally have a program to recycle used clothing to prevent them being sent to the landfill.

Target rates in the 20-30% range for Corporate Human Rights Benchmark with a poor rating for transparency. They showed poor handling of the 2013 mass data breach and still have not effectively solved the issue that caused it, and has poor workplace ethical guidelines for employees that in 2015 resulted in a fatality and lawsuit. Although our rating is for Target's ethics themselves, some of the most ethical brands Target sells are Method, Burt's Bees, Annieâs Homegrown, TOMS, and Evol. Plans to phase out of mulesed wool (wool removed with the sheep's skin) by 2023. Claims their brand Up&Up is Cruelty-free, but provides no transparency about their animal practices. Does not allow employees to unionize. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Target scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 9/22, which is poor.

Fails to pay minimum living wage to workers, scored a 55/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which is above average. Participates in The Apparel and Footwear Supply Chain Transparency Pledge. Earned a B grade in mitigating against the risks of worker exploitation in their supply chains from Ethical Fashion Report. Fur-free, banned Angora use. Better Cotton Initiative member
Romwe is a fast-fashion giant with extremely poor transparency about how their practices affect others downstream. Considered a "Fast-Fashion brand to avoid at all costs."

H&M uses Uyghur slave labor and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. They contribute to child labor in Bangladesh, and in India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Rated a D Carbon Disclosure Project's Forests Score, which scores transparency in how their practices are working to avoid deforestation in their supply chain. Cruelty free, fur-free, uses RDS (Responsible Down Standard)-certified down, bans Angora, and PETA-vegan-approved for their vegan collections. Scored a 24% on 2019's Human Rights Benchmark.

Zara is a fast-fashion giant with a business model that prioritizes heavy micro-seasonality with new weekly arrivals. Evidence shows Zara uses Uyghur slave labor, and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. In India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Zara scored a (41-50%) Fashion Transparency rating. That being said, Inditex (a fashion group that owns Zara) began a "Close the Loop" program vowing to send nothing to landfills in 2023. This program seeks to exclusively use a circular model to recycle its clothing. As far as animal welfare, Zara does not use fur, angora, and products tested on animals, but does use untraced wool, leather, down, and exotic animal hair. Rates a 2.5/19.5 by WWF's cotton sourcing and traceability practices, and a 30% on the Forest 500 ranking. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

Gap uses Uyghur slave labor and fails to pay minimum living wage to any worker making their products. They scored a 35.4% on its human rights performance related to sourcing conflict minerals. Contributes to Bangladeshi garment labor abuse. Fails to provide evidence of ethical and sustainable cotton sourcing. Gap sources animal products of leather, wool and exotic animal hair, and does not use fur, down or exotic animal skin, along with banning use of Angora. Gap is a member of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety, and Make Fashion Circular program. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

Ikea is an accredited living wage employer but has poor supply chain management practices. Their environmental reports are not independently verified, and their sourcing of cotton is not transparent. They source factory farmed meat and leather, but have vowed to not use live-plucked feathers for their down material and have increased their plant-based options at their eateries. FSC (Forest Stewardship Council) certified, uses recycled and certified FSC wood, and has made much in strides for their sustainability practices, but their FSC certification has been revoked before and recent reports say they have been using illegally sourced beech wood from Ukraine. IKEA's practices are more in line with fast-furniture, forgoing some ethical practices to produce on a mass scale. IKEA uses two subsidiaries that are high-risk for tax-avoidance. Pledged to reach a circular waste model by 2030, and reduced its Carbon footprint by 15% in 2019. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, IKEA scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 19/22, which is well above average.

Walgreens has been making improvements towards sustainability with their recent large scale initiatives to reduce their carbon footprint by 15.3% in 2019. and diverted 93% of their waste from distribution facilities, much of it being safe, unused toiletries, food, and household items donated to Feeding America. Provides free and safe pharmaceutical waste disposal so the drugs do not affect fish and wildlife, which often causes hormone disruptions and reproductive ability downstream via bioaccumulation. Walgreens does test some of their products on animals, and sells cruelty-free and vegan items as well. They recently stopped doing business with coconut milk brands Aroy-D and Chaokoh that were found to abuse monkeys to collect their coconuts. Allegations of ethics law violations and breaches in prescription data.

Amazon has a severely low Forest 500 rating (9%), rates a tier 5 on the 2019 Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare Report (BBFAW) meaning they provide little evidence they are making strides to manage animal welfare in their practices. They have a 16/100 on the S&P global sustainability report and are identified as a company using Uyghur forced labor in China. Amazon has a  low transparency about e-waste and fails to publish restrictions on hazardous chemicals in its devices. They score a 10-20% ranking on Corporate Human Rights Benchmark (CHRB), and have low risk-management in global mineral mining and the workers involved, numerous lawsuits involving labor rights and have committed tax avoidance.

Walmart built a warehouse on top of sacred land near Teotihuacan Moon Pyramid despite public outcry, and there is evidence Walmart bribed government officials to change the building codes to allow this. In 2019, they finally paid a fine equivalent to 0.05% of their revenue for that year for admitting to violating federal anti-bribery law in Brazil, yet are still allowed to operate there. In 2017, Walmart contributed to the labor abuse of 4 toy manufacturers in China affecting workers with low wages, excessive overtime, dangerous work environments and poor living conditions. In India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Scored 2nd to worst in mineral mining practices for jewelry retail. Landed on 2018's top 10 corporate Criminals list for its treatment of employees and enabling of gender-based violence on workers in garment supplier factories in Asia. Scored 18.7/100 on its IPE Green Supply Chain practices, and is one of the world's worst plastic polluters. Scored 39% on the Forest 500 company rankings. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Walmart scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 13.3/22, which is average. Major plastic polluter. Sources unsustainable cotton. 22.7% on Corporate Human Rights Benchmark.

Tchibo's coffee is 100% Rainforest Alliance Certified sourced. They are a Biodiversity in Good Company member which ensures they've committed to the managing biodiversity conservation concerns in their systems. They have been a partner with the ACT initiative on living wages since 2018, however in 2019 Labour Behind the Label found that they provide no evidence in having paid living wages along their supply chain.
